items.title: Error importing User from django auth models
items.body:
Hey there,
I'm getting an error and I don't know why it is showing up.
It is a new django project. I'm running everything normally.

Except, on every code that imports:
`from django.contrib.auth.models import User`

It says:
`User model imported from django.contrib.auth.models pylint(imported-auth-user)`

It shows no error code, so I can't even remove it like I did with function doc string errors, in the .pylintrc file.

items.title: Pylint crashes if Django is not configured
items.body:
Hi there, starting with version 2.2.0 I'm seeing a crash if django is not properly configured. I'm assuming this is originating from https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint-django/issues/243. This happens even if the string foreign key is resolvable without using the Django runtime.

items.title: unused argument schema_editor in django data migrations
items.body:
in django when writing data migrations, the function definition would  like this

```python
def update_something(apps, schema_editor):
    # do something
```

here, `apps` and `schema_editor` will be passed by django when applying migration. There are cases where either of them will not be used. In such cases `pylint-django` should not complain `unused-argument` error.

EXPECTED : it is expected that to have a exception for this case

It happened many times that folks in our team removes `schema_editor` when `pylint` complains with `unused-argument` and that result into errors.

items.title: ForeignKey("auth.Group") leads to AstroidImportError
items.body:
With the latest releases of [astroid](https://github.com/PyCQA/astroid), pylint, and pylint-django I noticed that using `group = models.ForeignKey("auth.Group", on_delete=models.CASCADE)` in a model leads to an exception when running pylint.

The problem is `"auth.Group"`.  transforms/foreignkey.py [rewrites](https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint-django/blob/4f37bf33543b5d99cf11306f14251430beb60548/pylint_django/transforms/foreignkey.py#L93) the `auth` to `auth.models` which leads to `astroid.exceptions.AstroidImportError: Failed to import module auth.models with error: No module named auth.models.`.

A workaround is to add `from django.contrib.auth.models import Group` and change the field to `group = models.ForeignKey(Group, on_delete=models.CASCADE)`.

Here's a minimal example: https://github.com/michael-k/pylinttest
Clone the repo and run the following commands to reproduce the exeption:

```sh
docker build --pull --no-cache --tag="pylinttest:latest" .
docker run --rm --volume=$(pwd):/code pylinttest:latest pylint /code/pylinttest/main/models.py
```


> make sure to post the output of `pip freeze`

See https://github.com/michael-k/pylinttest/blob/master/requirements.txt (generated with pip-compile)

items.title: The tests are failing
items.body:
This project uses the `test_functional.py` from Pylint's test module. Unfortunately with Pylint 2.4.0 (https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/commit/33b8185a455c1686d038258697bb93005f2441c2) the test module isn't installed anymore when installing Pylint.

### Workaround
The tests can still be run with Pylint 2.3.1.

items.title: Too broad suppression of `unused-argument` warnings
items.body:
`pylint-django` currently suppresses the `unused-argument` warning when a function/method contains an argument called `request`. The reason to ignore these warnings for an argument named `request` was discussed in #155 and implemented with commit https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint-django/commit/e4c8fc70af33b227371c6e0e80b0dccf0ad157fa.

Unfortunately the warning is also suppressed for all other function arguments. Therefore every other unused argument of the function will not be reported. Unused arguments can be an indicator for bugs and these warnings should only be explicitly silenced.

### Example

``` python
def user_detail(request, user_id):
    # nothing is done with user_id
    return JsonResponse({'username': 'steve'})
```

Pylint should issue  a warning that `user_id` is unused. But because the function has an argument named `request` no warning is issued.

items.title: Add all handlers to good names.
items.body:
`C0103: Constant name "handler403" doesn't conform to UPPER_CASE naming style (invalid-name)`

All handlers must be in good names. Handlers are handler400, handler403, handler404.

items.title: RFC: new checker: hard-coded usage of auth.User/User.objects
items.body:
Django recommends that you do not use the `User` model directly. Neither to issue queries against it, nor to use it as a foreign key reference. Instead you should be using the `get_user_model()` function and the `AUTH_USER_MODEL` setting.

The reason for all of this is that this can be overridden and applications which do not hard-code the values are in theory more portable downstream. That is they can be used directly inside an environment where the User model has been overridden. 

In another project of mine we have a simple checker which warns for both of the above scenarios: https://github.com/kiwitcms/Kiwi/blob/master/kiwi_lint/auth_user.py

Questions are: 

- Do people want to have this in pylint-django (kind of makes sense) ? 
- Should it be enabled by default or made an extension like `pylint_django.checkers.db_performance` ?

Please vote and comment for your preferences.

items.title: AstroidImportError when ForeignKey points to app not in root module
items.body:
I have a project structure where Django apps live in an `apps/` directory. This makes the import path for a model at `apps.myapp.models.MyModel`.

When pylint_django processes the ForeignKey, it tries to load `myapp.models`, resulting in an `astroid.exceptions.AstroidImportError`. The only way around it as I see is to actually read the contents of `INSTALLED_APPS` settings variable.

items.title: GenericForeignKey regression after #224
items.body:
```
$ pip freeze | grep pylint
pylint==2.3.1
pylint-django==2.0.8
pylint-plugin-utils==0.5
```

I tested with version 2.0.6, the last version before #224 was merged, and that version doesn't have this issue.

I'm getting a `TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not iterable` for a model similar to the following example. It's [triggered by this line](https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint-django/pull/224/files#diff-1bbed731b242312a86f3f314c3682343R26).

```
# models.py

from django.contrib.contenttypes.fields import GenericForeignKey                
from django.contrib.contenttypes.models import ContentType
from django.db import models

class Ownership(models.Model):
    owner_type = models.ForeignKey(ContentType, models.CASCADE)
    owner_id = models.PositiveIntegerField()
    owner = GenericForeignKey("owner_type", "owner_id")
```

items.title: pylint-django doesn't recognise ForeignKey models when using the `to` kwarg
items.body:
In addition to not recognising the model when it's supplied as a string, the following does not work

`related = models.ForeignKey(to=Other, on_delete=models.SET_NULL)`

the linter works as expected with

`related = models.ForeignKey(Other, on_delete=models.SET_NULL)`

Is it possible to allow kwarg usage? I prefer being explicit so that it's easy to find all references to a model.

items.title: 2.0.6 appears to allow various warnings that used to be ignored
items.body:
After an upgrade to v2.0.6 (pylint 2.3.0) I'm getting various warnings of things that would otherwise have been fine. There's a small number of them, so rather than list each as a separate issue, I'll give a flavour of them here. If separate issues would be more helpful please do say so and I'll be happy to raise them.

With a large body of Django code that, with v2.0.5 of django-pylint (pylint 2.2.2), passed 10/10, I'm seeing warnings such as:

- `line-too-long` in many migration modules.
- `Missing module docstring (missing-docstring)` in many migration modules.
- `Missing class docstring (missing-docstring)` in many migration modules.
- `Constant name "register" doesn't conform to UPPER_CASE naming style (invalid-name)` in a `templatetags` module, complaining about a `register = template.Library()` line.
- `Module name "0006_auto_20190204_1124" doesn't conform to snake_case naming style (invalid-name)` in a migration module.

items.title: Do not use versions 2.0.3 and 2.0.4, use 2.0.5
items.body:
Use the latest 2.0.5

@carlio - when you've built 2.0.3 you've tagged it as 2.0.4 in git and for some reason 2.0.4 on PyPI. Maybe you had a built which you pushed unintentionally. 

Then I rewrote the 2.0.4 tag on GitHub this morning and also went back to create a 2.0.3 tag to keep a reference to the previous version. Then I uploaded to PyPI which happily accepted the wheel package for 2.0.4 and then failed because a tar.gz tagged 2.0.4 already existed.


I've pushed a 2.0.5 version in an attempt to clean up this mess and updated changelog. You can close this issue when you read it.

items.title: Tidy up compat
items.body:
As part of #201 #203 fixes in #204 I just added the old `compat.py` back in.

I only used the `YES`==`Uninferable` for now but I did not revert any other changes as they clearly work.

Since this library has open ended ranges, I think it is useful to have a single place to put the various hacks/workarounds that come from supporting `pylint==2.1`->`pylint==latest` as is the current case.

Ideally all those hacks should go into the same place for easy of cleaning. The previous code (and the code that is now there) were not really cleaned out enough and there's lots of unecessary bits.

This issues is to:

1) clear out the previous legacy things which are no longer useful due to not supporting ancient pylint versions, eg the method mis-spellings
2) figure out how to add new fixes for newer pylint/astroid etc releases.

The fact is that as pylint-django is used in lots of build processes in lots of configurations, any time there is a bug due to bad code in pylint-django or upstream changes, lots of people will waste time figuring out why their builds now error and we will get bug reports. It's in the best interests of everyone to have a good strategy to cope with this - trust me from 5 years of this :-)

@atodorov That is mostly for you to read

items.title: Custom error code for not loaded related model
items.body:
In my opinion `Instance of 'ForeignKey' has no '..' member` errors that show up on ForeignKeys that referend models with a string path is not an issue with `pylint_django` plugin, but rather with the code that is being checked. It is better to communicate this to the plugin users via an error message tied directly to the ForeignKey, rather than via the plugin documentation.

When a model that is referenced by `'app_name.ModelName'` string is not loaded when `pylint_django` inspect a model class, it should produce a new error (e.g., `E5102: Referenced model 'app_name.ModelName' not loaded.`). This way it will be much clearer to the user what is the issue with the code that they wrote. If the user need the circular dependency there, they would be able to disable the error by adding `# pylint: disable=E5102` to the line where ForeignKey is defined.

It would be great if `no-member` errors related to that ForeignKey were suppressed by `pylint_django`, so that if the user would only need to suppress the original `E5102` error on the line where ForeignKey is defined, instead of on every line where it is referenced. Does anyone know if it is possible to suppress errors like this in pylint?

items.title: False-positive no-self-argument in factory.post_generation method
items.body:
In factory_boy, post_generation methods defined via the `factory.post_generation` decorator receive the model object, not self (as in the factory) as first argument. We should silence these errors.

Reference: https://factoryboy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/reference.html?highlight=post_generation#extracting-parameters (note the first argument is called `obj`, not `self`)

items.title: Custom good names
items.body:
After change in pull request https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint-django/pull/109 seems to be broken to ability to set own good names. Example pylintrc:

```
[MASTER]
load-plugins=pylint_django

[BASIC]
good-names=_,dt,e,f,default_app_config,logger
```

In version v0.7.2 it was working properly but starting version 0.8.0 it can be one or other. Probably previous version was merging two lists of good names which is not the case now.

items.title: Proposal: rule to suggest using fields instead of exclude in ModelForm
items.body:
Using `exclude` in ModelForm.Meta is an antipattern and can easily become a security issue if one is not careful. ModelForms should always define their fields explicitly.

I can contribute a patch if you are interested in this. Also, I'm not sure what to name this rule. `modelform-uses-exclude`?

items.title: model-missing-unicode false positive for subclassed model
items.body:
Hi

For this code block ([original source](https://github.com/mozilla/treeherder/blob/572c75d8ecdbbd385f1177284547d8410401140c/treeherder/model/models.py#L40-L42)):

```python
from django.db import models
from django.utils.encoding import python_2_unicode_compatible


@python_2_unicode_compatible
class NamedModel(models.Model):
    id = models.AutoField(primary_key=True)
    name = models.CharField(max_length=100, unique=True)

    class Meta:
        abstract = True

    def __str__(self):
        return self.name


class Product(NamedModel):
    class Meta:
        db_table = 'product'
```

pylint with pylint_django reports:
```
treeherder/model/models.py:40,0: No __unicode__ method on model (Product) (W5101: model-missing-unicode)
```

The parent model already uses the `@python_2_unicode_compatible` decorator, so it seems that instead of W5101, this should be W5103?

The above was using:
Python 2.7.14
Django==1.11.12
pylint==1.8.4
pylint-django==0.9.4
pylint-plugin-utils==0.2.6
astroid==1.6.3

items.title: Suppress protected-access warning about User._default_manager()
items.body:
Hi

For this method ([here](https://github.com/mozilla/treeherder/blob/0ea4717230c2172e9dbde2ca7897cd5ab276f919/treeherder/auth/backends.py#L151-L156)):

```python
from django.contrib.auth.models import User


class AuthBackend(object):

    # ...

    def get_user(self, user_id):
        try:
            return User._default_manager.get(pk=user_id)
        except User.DoesNotExist:
            return None
```

pylint warns about:
```
Access to a protected member _default_manager of a client class (W0212: protected-access)
```

This seems like something that pylint-django might be able to suppress? (Given that `._default_manager()` is an [official API](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.11/topics/db/managers/#django.db.models.Model._default_manager))

items.title: bad operand type for unary -: IntegerField
items.body:
One of the pylint warnings I get is:

`./paperwork/models/deliverables.py:52: error (E1130, invalid-unary-operand-type, Deadline.pretty_offset) bad operand type for unary -: IntegerField`

The method in question is:

```
def pretty_offset(self):
        """ convert deadline information to human-readable"""
        if self.offset > 0:
            return str(self.offset) + " " + \
                Duration.pretty_print(self.duration) + " after"
        elif self.offset < 0:
            return str(-self.offset) + " " + \
                Duration.pretty_print(self.duration) + " before"
        return "the same " + Duration.pretty_print(self.duration) + " as"
```

If I'm reading the code right, it appears that the IntegerField is described in some way to the manager such that it should know it returns an int - (lines 11 and 35 [here](https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint-django/blob/master/pylint_django/transforms/fields.py)). However, that isn't happening in my case. I can a small codebase to replicate if necessary, but I want to make sure it's nothing stupid on my end.

items.title: Difference in wheel and tar.gz packages
items.body:
Since the changes in 0.9.2 which update the location of the tests/ directory and the way we include other files inside the package I've noticed a difference between the tar.gz package and a wheel package.

The wheel package doesn't include .rc or .txt files required for the tests and more importantly it doesn't include all the transformations files.

I have not examined older versions to see if this problem is present there.

Note to self: need to investigate why is this happening and also add a sanity test/make target to build the packages and compare the contents. While at it also add a sanity check to make sure we're not inclyding pyc files into the package.

items.title: Tests should not be installed, or find_packages() is incorrectly defined
items.body:
I think *pylint-django* should not install tests (for sure, not under `.../site-packages/test` directory). Please, apply this patch to omit test installation.

```
--- setup.py.orig
+++ setup.py
@@ -7,10 +7,8 @@ from setuptools import setup, find_packa
 
 VERSION = '0.9.1'
 PACKAGES = find_packages(exclude=[
-    '*.tests',
-    '*.tests.*',
-    'tests.*',
-    'tests',
+    'test.*',
+    'test',
 ])
 
 SHORT_DESCRIPTION = 'A Pylint plugin to help Pylint understand the Django web framework'
```

items.title: Option to Error with Default on New Field
items.body:
When adding a column to an existing table with a default value, django will lock the table while performing the update. Django best practices are to create a new column with `null=True` and *no* default value. 

Reference: 

[Stack Overflow Summary](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41502331/migration-of-django-field-with-default-value-to-postgresql-database)

[Django Docs](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.11/topics/migrations/#backend-support)

Can you add an option to lint for this best practice. Deploying to a production server with a default value set has a high probability of resulting in downtime.

items.title: Incorrectly identify queryset as not iterable when model manager is a subclass
items.body:
Since upgrading to version 0.8.0 (and pylint 1.8) we're incorrectly getting an error that a queryset is not iterable:

```
E: 49,29: Non-iterable value MyModel.objects.filter(foo=bar) is used in an iterating context (not-an-iterable)
```

`MyModel` in this case is a subclass of a model that has `objects` set to a subclass of of the usual manager (in particular, it uses `model_utils.managers.InheritanceManager`)

Similar uses where the standard manager is used does not cause this error, and we did not get this error with previous versions of pylint and pylint-django.

items.title: make django a requirement, or somehow let users know that it has to be installed
items.body:
Hi,

thanks for an awesome plugin; it was a relief to find when I introduced pylint to an existing django project and was swarmed with errors from django `class Meta` and so forth.

My team had an issue with getting the plugin to work in some instances.

Specifically; using a virtualenv/global installation of pylint and plylint django which did not include django. It may seems silly, but I think it's a valid usage pattern.

The django typical lint errors kept being reported, and we were pretty confused as to why. Of course, django had to be installed on path.

I didn't see anywhere in the readme that django had to be installed. It's a minor nuisance to solve, but it'd be nice to help the next person by either:

* letting them know in the readme
* raising an error when pylint_django is loaded if django is not installed
* adding django to requirements in `setup.py`

I'm in favour of the last option. Glad to create a PR for the option that the maintainer(s) prefer, if any.

Thanks

items.title: duplicate-except throws red-herring on DoesNotExist
items.body:
Hi guys, I have the following issue.
I raised it originally to the pylint team who thinks this is actually due to some processing you are doing with the DoesNotExist (I guess for other code checks)!

https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/issues/1050
### Steps to reproduce
1. in a django project with 2 models
2. create a piece of code like this

```
    try:
        print("foo")
    except Model1.DoesNotExist:
        print("bar")
    except Model2.DoesNotExist:
        print("baz")
```
### Current behavior

This raises a W0705 duplicate-except saying it's catching django.core.exceptions.ObjectDoesNotExist. both those exception (as far as I understand it) are indeed inheriting from ObjectDoesNotExist (common ancestor), but they are not the same class
### Expected behavior

Do not raise this issue on common ancestor
### pylint --version output

pylint 1.5.6,
astroid 1.4.6
Python 2.7.12 (default, Jun 29 2016, 14:05:02)
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 7.3.0 (clang-703.0.31)]

``` python
from mongoengine.errors import DoesNotExist, MultipleObjectsReturned

class Document(object):

    objects = None

    id = None
    pk = None

    MultipleObjectsReturned = MultipleObjectsReturned
    DoesNotExist = DoesNotExist

    save = lambda: None
```

which member objects gives a None. The fact in mongoengine it should be a mongoengine.QuerySetManager, which is callable, and can be used as query method.

items.title: Maintenance status?
items.body:
Can you give us an idea of what to expect with pull requests being merged, and new versions released?  A number of improvements are in the iXce fork: https://github.com/iXce/pylint-django

Should we continue to wait, or should we move onto a new fork?

items.title: _meta is official API
items.body: With `_meta` being brought into the public API, it makes sense to exclude it from `protected-access`.

items.title: Old School Exclusion for DRF Should be on Base Serializer
items.body: The exclude for `Meta` being an old school class should be on `BaseSerializer` no `ModelSerializer. BaseSerializers can have Meta too: https://github.com/tomchristie/django-rest-framework/blob/8c1365e315256f892dced348cf485bf966429596/rest_framework/serializers.py#L132

items.title: Disable model-missing-unicode (W5101) not working
items.body:
In pylintrc disabled the model-missing-unicode error, But its not working as we expected. We have integrated with prospector.

**In .pylintrc,**

disable=W5101 # W5101 - No **unicode** method on model

**## OutPut**
  Line: 177
    pylint: model-missing-unicode / No **unicode** method on model (Model1)
  Line: 184
    pylint: model-no-explicit-unicode / Model does not explicitly define **unicode** (Model2)
  Line: 190
    pylint: model-missing-unicode / No **unicode** method on model (Model3)
  Line: 199
    pylint: model-missing-unicode / No **unicode** method on model (Model4)

Note: Other disable options(cyclic-import, locally-disabled) is working fine

items.body:


items.title: View.kwargs is an unsubscriptable-object
items.body:
The following code generates an error:

```
    return super().get_queryset()\
        .filter(capability=self.kwargs['capability'])
```

views.py [unsubscriptable-object] Value 'self.kwargs' is unsubscriptable [python/pylint]

items.title: [no-member] Instance of 'Item' has no 'save' member
items.body:
I discovered pylint-django after finding this [stackoverflow thread](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/115977/using-pylint-with-django).

However I still have some false pylint errors working with django:

```
[no-member] Instance of 'Item' has no 'full_clean' member
[no-member] Instance of 'Item' has no 'save' member
```

Is this something that pylint-django can help out with at all? Or is it some peculiar behaviour of django with forms and models that makes hard to deal with?
